required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on May 29, 2018
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Post-operative Dental Pain Study Comparing Two Different Dosage of Analgesic Efficacy
clinical_study.official_title: A Study to Compare the Analgesic Efficacy of Two Different Paracetamol Doses as Measured by Post-operative Pain Relief

brief_summary.textblock: GlaxoSmithKline will be conducting this trial to compare analgesic efficacy of paracetamol 1000 mg vs 650 mg. The post-surgical dental pain model will be used to evaluate the analgesic efficacy of paracetamol. Each subject will be enrolled in the study for up to six weeks. The duration of the entire study will be approximately 18 weeks. Each subject will have to come to the clinic for three visits (Screening, Treatment and Follow up visits).

primary_outcome.measure: Sum of Pain Relief and Pain Intensity Differences From 0 to 6 Hours (SPRID 6 Hours)
primary_outcome.time_frame: Every two hours from Baseline to 6 hours post dose
primary_outcome.description: SPRID:Sum of Pain Intensity Difference (SPID) and Total Pain Relief (TOTPAR) at each post-dosing time-point. SPRID score ranged from -5.8 (least pain relief) to 40.3 (highest pain relief). SPID and TOTPAR were calculated as weighted sums of Pain Intensity Differences (PID) and Pain Relief Scores (PRS) at each measurement time, respectively. PID was derived by subtracting the pain severity score at a given post-dosing time-point from the baseline [pain severity score range:0-no pain, 1-mild pain, 2-moderate pain, 3-severe pain using a 4-point categorical Verbal Rating Scale (VRS)]. If the subject rated pain intensity as 2 or 3, pain was assessed using a 100 mm Visual Analog Scale (VAS) [0 (no pain), 100 (worst pain)]. VAS scores were converted into PID scores by subtracting them from baseline pain scores. PRS was assessed on 5-point categorical pain relief rating scale [0-no relief, 1-little relief, 2-some relief, 3-a lot of relief, 4-complete relief]

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to Confirmed First Perceptible Relief
secondary_outcome.description: Participants recorded the time to first perceptible relief by starting the first stopwatch at the time of dosing and stopping it when he/she experienced the first perceptible pain relief. The first perceptible pain relief was confirmed if the participant also stopped the second stopwatch indicating meaningful relief.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to Onset of Meaningful Pain Relief
secondary_outcome.description: Participants recorded the time to meaningful relief by stopping a second stopwatch when they first began to experience meaningful relief.

secondary_outcome.measure: Time to Start Using Rescue Medication
secondary_outcome.description: Median time of use of rescue medication by participants.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants Who Took Rescue Medication at 2 Hours
secondary_outcome.description: Percentage of participants who received rescue medication at different time points post dose.

secondary_outcome.measure: Percentage of Participants Who Took Rescue Medication at 6 Hours
secondary_outcome.description: Percentage of participants who received rescue medication at different time points post dose.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Every two hours from baseline to 2 hours post dose
secondary_outcome.description: SPRID:Sum of Pain Intensity Difference (SPID) and Total Pain Relief (TOTPAR) at each post-dosing time-point. SPRID score ranged from -1.8 (least pain relief) to 12.3 (highest pain relief). SPID and TOTPAR were calculated as weighted sums of Pain Intensity Differences (PID) and Pain Relief Scores (PRS) at each measurement time, respectively. PID was derived by subtracting the pain severity score at a given post-dosing time-point from the baseline [pain severity score range:0-no pain, 1-mild pain, 2-moderate pain, 3-severe pain using a 4-point categorical Verbal Rating Scale (VRS)]. If the subject rated pain intensity as 2 or 3, pain was assessed using a 100 mm Visual Analog Scale (VAS) [0 (no pain), 100 (worst pain)]. VAS scores were converted into PID scores by subtracting them from baseline pain scores. PRS was assessed on 5-point categorical pain relief rating scale [0-no relief, 1-little relief, 2-some relief, 3-a lot of relief, 4-complete relief

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Every two hours from baseline to 4 hours post dose
secondary_outcome.description: SPRID:Sum of Pain Intensity Difference (SPID) and Total Pain Relief (TOTPAR) at each post-dosing time-point. SPRID score ranged from -3.8 (least pain relief) to 26.3 (highest pain relief). SPID and TOTPAR were calculated as weighted sums of Pain Intensity Differences (PID) and Pain Relief Scores (PRS) at each measurement time, respectively. PID was derived by subtracting the pain severity score at a given post-dosing time-point from the baseline [pain severity score range:0-no pain, 1-mild pain, 2-moderate pain, 3-severe pain using a 4-point categorical Verbal Rating Scale (VRS)]. If the subject rated pain intensity as 2 or 3, pain was assessed using a 100 mm Visual Analog Scale (VAS) [0 (no pain), 100 (worst pain)]. VAS scores were converted into PID scores by subtracting them from baseline pain scores. PRS was assessed on 5-point categorical pain relief rating scale [0-no relief, 1-little relief, 2-some relief, 3-a lot of relief, 4-complete relief

secondary_outcome.measure: Total Pain Relief Score (TOTPAR) at 2 Hours
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Every two hours from baseline to 2 hours post dose
secondary_outcome.description: TOTPAR was calculated as sum of products of pain relief (PR) at a given time-point (t) with the time-interval from that time-point to the previous time-point (t-1). The time-intervals used were 0-15, 15-30, 30-45, 45-60, 60-90, 90-120. Higher score indicated greater pain relief. TOTPARt = ∑PR x (timet - timet-1). PR score was assessed at each of the above time-points based on a 5-point categorical scale [0-no relief, 1-little relief, 2-meaningful relief, 3-a lot of relief, 4-complete relief].

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Every two hours from baseline to 4 hours post dose
secondary_outcome.description: TOTPAR was calculated as sum of products of pain relief (PR) at a given time-point (t) with the time-interval from that time-point to the previous time-point (t-1). The time-intervals used were 0-15, 15-30, 30-45, 45-60, 60-90, 90-120, 120-240. Higher score indicated greater pain relief. TOTPARt = ∑PR x (timet - timet-1). PR score was assessed at each of the above time-points based on a 5-point categorical scale [0-no relief, 1-little relief, 2-meaningful relief, 3-a lot of relief, 4-complete relief].

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Every two hours from baseline to 6 hours post dose
secondary_outcome.description: TOTPAR was calculated as sum of products of pain relief (PR) at a given time-point (t) with the time-interval from that time-point to the previous time-point (t-1). The time-intervals used were 0-15, 15-30, 30-45, 45-60, 60-90, 90-120, 120-240, 240-300 and 300-360. Higher score indicated greater pain relief. TOTPARt = ∑PR x (timet - timet-1). PR score was assessed at each of the above time-points based on a 5-point categorical scale [0-no relief, 1-little relief, 2-meaningful relief, 3-a lot of relief, 4-complete relief].

secondary_outcome.measure: Sum of Pain Intensity Difference (SPID) Scores at 2 Hours
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Every two hours from baseline to 2 hours post dose
secondary_outcome.description: SPID was calculated as sum of products of Pain Intensity Differences (PID) at a given time-point (t) with the time-interval from that time-point to the previous time-point (t-1). The time-intervals used were 0-15, 15-30, 30-45, 45-60, 60-90, 90-120. Positive and higher scores indicate greater reduction in pain. SPIDt = ∑PID x (timet - timet-1) Pain Intensity was assessed at baseline and at each time-point based on a 4-point categorical Verbal Rating Scale (VRS) scale: 0-no pain, 1-mild pain, 2-moderate pain, 3-severe pain. If the subject rated pain intensity as "2" or "3", pain was assessed using a 100 mm Visual Analog Scale (VAS) [0 (no pain), 100 (worst pain)]. VAS scores were converted into PID scores by subtracting them from pain scores taken at baseline.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Every two hours from baseline to 4 hours post dose
secondary_outcome.description: SPID was calculated as sum of products of Pain Intensity Differences (PID) at a given time-point (t) with the time-interval from that time-point to the previous time-point (t-1). The time-intervals used were 0-15, 15-30, 30-45, 45-60, 60-90, 90-120, 120-240. Positive and higher scores indicate greater reduction in pain. SPIDt = ∑PID x (timet - timet-1) Pain Intensity was assessed at baseline and at each time-point based on a 4-point categorical Verbal Rating Scale (VRS) scale: 0-no pain, 1-mild pain, 2-moderate pain, 3-severe pain. If the subject rated pain intensity as "2" or "3", pain was assessed using a 100 mm Visual Analog Scale (VAS) [0 (no pain), 100 (worst pain)]. VAS scores were converted into PID scores by subtracting them from pain scores taken at baseline.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: Every two hours from baseline to 6 hours post dose
secondary_outcome.description: SPID was calculated as sum of products of Pain Intensity Differences (PID) at a given time-point (t) with the time-interval from that time-point to the previous time-point (t-1). The time-intervals used were 0-15, 15-30, 30-45, 45-60, 60-90, 90-120, 120-240, 240-300 and 300-360. Positive and higher scores indicate greater reduction in pain. SPIDt = ∑PID x (timet - timet-1) Pain Intensity was assessed at baseline and at each time-point based on a 4-point categorical Verbal Rating Scale (VRS) scale: 0-no pain, 1-mild pain, 2-moderate pain, 3-severe pain. If the subject rated pain intensity as "2" or "3", pain was assessed using a 100 mm Visual Analog Scale (VAS) [0 (no pain), 100 (worst pain)]. VAS scores were converted into PID scores by subtracting them from pain scores taken at baseline.

secondary_outcome.measure: Participants Global Assessment to Response to Treatment (PGART)
secondary_outcome.description: PGART was measured by a score in a scale from 0-4: 0- Poor; 1- Fair 2- Good; 3- Very Good; 4- Excellent.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- Subjects aged 18 to 45 years with moderate-to-severe dental pain as assessed by verbal rating scale (VRS) and confirmed by a score of at least 50 mm out of 100 mm using a visual analogue (VAS) following the surgical removal of up to two mandibular third molars. If only one mandibular third molar is removed, it must be a full bony impaction. If two mandibular third molars are removed, both may be partial bony impactions OR there may be a combination of one full bony impaction with the second tooth being erupted, soft tissue impaction, or partial bony impaction. Ipsilateral maxillary third molars may be removed at the surgeon's discretion, regardless of impaction level.
Exclusion Criteria:
- Pregnant and lactating females
- Allergy/intolerance to study materials or nitrous oxide or local anaesthetic used during surgery
- Current or recurrent liver, kidney or cardiac disease, stomach ulcers, gastrointestinal bleeding, gastroesophageal reflux disease, bronchospasm, rhinitis, urticaria or asthma

participant_flow.recruitment_details: Participants were recruited at the clinical site.
participant_flow.pre_assignment_details: Of 722 screened participants, 321 were considered to be screen failures. Remaining 401 were randomized to study treatments.

group.title: Paracetamol Caplet 1000 Milligrams (mg)
group.description: Participants were administered with two paracetamol fast dissolving (FD) 500 mg caplets (Total dose= 1000 mg), and two placebo standard paracetamol caplets with 150 milliliter (mL) of water through oral route.

group.title: Paracetamol Caplet 650 mg
group.description: Participants were administered with two standard paracetamol 325 mg caplets (Total dose = 650 mg) and two placebo FD caplets, with 150 mL of water through oral route.

group.title: Placebo Caplet
group.description: Participants were administered with two standard and two FD placebo caplets, with 150 mL of water through oral route.

group.title: Paracetamol Caplet 1000mg
group.description: Participants were administered with two paracetamol FD 500 mg caplets (Total dose= 1000 mg), and two placebo standard paracetamol caplets with 150 mL of water through oral route.

group.title: Paracetamol Caplet 650 mg
group.description: Participants were administered with two standard paracetamol 325 mg caplets (Total dose = 650 mg) and two placebo FD caplets, with 150 mL of water through oral route.

group.title: Placebo Caplet
group.description: Participants were administered with two standard and two FD placebo caplets, with 150 mL of water through oral route.

group.title: Total
group.description: Total of all reporting groups

measure.title: Number of participants with pain severity score measured on a rating scale
measure.description: Pain severity score was assessed on a 4-point categorical verbal rating scale. Total possible pain severity score range was no pain, mild pain, moderate and severe.

outcome.title: Sum of Pain Relief and Pain Intensity Differences From 0 to 6 Hours (SPRID 6 Hours)
outcome.description: SPRID:Sum of Pain Intensity Difference (SPID) and Total Pain Relief (TOTPAR) at each post-dosing time-point. SPRID score ranged from -5.8 (least pain relief) to 40.3 (highest pain relief). SPID and TOTPAR were calculated as weighted sums of Pain Intensity Differences (PID) and Pain Relief Scores (PRS) at each measurement time, respectively. PID was derived by subtracting the pain severity score at a given post-dosing time-point from the baseline [pain severity score range:0-no pain, 1-mild pain, 2-moderate pain, 3-severe pain using a 4-point categorical Verbal Rating Scale (VRS)]. If the subject rated pain intensity as 2 or 3, pain was assessed using a 100 mm Visual Analog Scale (VAS) [0 (no pain), 100 (worst pain)]. VAS scores were converted into PID scores by subtracting them from baseline pain scores. PRS was assessed on 5-point categorical pain relief rating scale [0-no relief, 1-little relief, 2-some relief, 3-a lot of relief, 4-complete relief]
outcome.time_frame: Every two hours from Baseline to 6 hours post dose
outcome.population: Intent to Treat (ITT) population: All participants who received one study treatment and have at least one post-baseline efficacy assessment.

group.title: Paracetamol Caplet 1000mg
group.description: Participants were administered with two paracetamol FD 500 mg caplets (Total dose= 1000 mg), and two placebo standard paracetamol caplets with 150 mL of water through oral route.

group.description: Participants were administered with two standard paracetamol 325 mg caplets (Total dose = 650 mg) and two placebo FD caplets, with 150 mL of water through oral route.

group.title: Placebo Caplet
group.description: Participants were administered with two standard and two FD placebo caplets, with 150 mL of water through oral route.

measure.title: Sum of Pain Relief and Pain Intensity Differences From 0 to 6 Hours (SPRID 6 Hours)
measure.description: SPRID:Sum of Pain Intensity Difference (SPID) and Total Pain Relief (TOTPAR) at each post-dosing time-point. SPRID score ranged from -5.8 (least pain relief) to 40.3 (highest pain relief). SPID and TOTPAR were calculated as weighted sums of Pain Intensity Differences (PID) and Pain Relief Scores (PRS) at each measurement time, respectively. PID was derived by subtracting the pain severity score at a given post-dosing time-point from the baseline [pain severity score range:0-no pain, 1-mild pain, 2-moderate pain, 3-severe pain using a 4-point categorical Verbal Rating Scale (VRS)]. If the subject rated pain intensity as 2 or 3, pain was assessed using a 100 mm Visual Analog Scale (VAS) [0 (no pain), 100 (worst pain)]. VAS scores were converted into PID scores by subtracting them from baseline pain scores. PRS was assessed on 5-point categorical pain relief rating scale [0-no relief, 1-little relief, 2-some relief, 3-a lot of relief, 4-complete relief]
measure.population: Intent to Treat (ITT) population: All participants who received one study treatment and have at least one post-baseline efficacy assessment.

analysis.groups_desc: Null hypothesis considered no difference in SPRID^6h between Paracetamol 1000 mg caplet and Paracetamol 650 mg caplet.
analysis.method_desc: ANCOVA model included factors for treatment as a fixed effect and baseline assessment of pain intensity (VAS score) as a covariate.
analysis.estimate_desc: Difference is first named treatment minus second named treatment such that a positive difference favors the first named treatment.

analysis.groups_desc: Null hypothesis considered no difference in SPRID^6h between Paracetamol 1000 mg caplet and placebo caplet.
analysis.method_desc: ANCOVA model included factors for treatment as a fixed effect and baseline assessment of pain intensity (VAS score) as a covariate.
analysis.estimate_desc: Difference is first named treatment minus second named treatment such that a positive difference favors the first named treatment.

analysis.groups_desc: Null hypothesis considered no difference in SPRID^6h between Paracetamol 650 mg caplet and placebo caplet.
analysis.method_desc: ANCOVA model included factors for treatment as a fixed effect and baseline assessment of pain intensity (VAS score) as a covariate.
analysis.estimate_desc: Difference is first named treatment minus second named treatment such that a positive difference favors the first named treatment.

outcome.title: Time to Confirmed First Perceptible Relief
outcome.description: Participants recorded the time to first perceptible relief by starting the first stopwatch at the time of dosing and stopping it when he/she experienced the first perceptible pain relief. The first perceptible pain relief was confirmed if the participant also stopped the second stopwatch indicating meaningful relief.
outcome.population: ITT population: All participants who received one study treatment and have at least one post-baseline efficacy assessment. Participants who did not achieve first perceptible pain relief during the 6 hours of the study period or took rescue medication were censored at the time 360 minutes.

outcome.title: Total Pain Relief Score (TOTPAR) at 2 Hours
outcome.description: TOTPAR was calculated as sum of products of pain relief (PR) at a given time-point (t) with the time-interval from that time-point to the previous time-point (t-1). The time-intervals used were 0-15, 15-30, 30-45, 45-60, 60-90, 90-120. Higher score indicated greater pain relief. TOTPARt = ∑PR x (timet – timet-1). PR score was assessed at each of the above time-points based on a 5-point categorical scale [0-no relief, 1-little relief, 2-meaningful relief, 3-a lot of relief, 4-complete relief].
outcome.time_frame: Every two hours from baseline to 2 hours post dose
outcome.population: ITT population: All participants who received one study treatment and have at least one post-baseline efficacy assessment. Participants who did not achieve first perceptible pain relief during the 6 hours of the study period or took rescue medication were censored at the time 360 minutes.

PR score was assessed at each of the above time-points based on a 5-point categorical scale [0-no relief, 1-little relief, 2-meaningful relief, 3-a lot of relief, 4-complete relief].

measure.title: TOTPAR at 6 Hours
measure.description: TOTPAR was calculated as sum of products of pain relief (PR) at a given time-point (t) with the time-interval from that time-point to the previous time-point (t-1). The time-intervals used were 0-15, 15-30, 30-45, 45-60, 60-90, 90-120, 120-240, 240-300 and 300-360. Higher score indicated greater pain relief. TOTPARt = ∑PR x (timet – timet-1). PR score was assessed at each of the above time-points based on a 5-point categorical scale [0-no relief, 1-little relief, 2-meaningful relief, 3-a lot of relief, 4-complete relief].
measure.population: ITT population: All participants who received one study treatment and have at least one post-baseline efficacy assessment. Participants who did not achieve first perceptible pain relief during the 6 hours of the study period or took rescue medication were censored at the time 360 minutes.

outcome.title: Sum of Pain Intensity Difference (SPID) Scores at 2 Hours
outcome.description: SPID was calculated as sum of products of Pain Intensity Differences (PID) at a given time-point (t) with the time-interval from that time-point to the previous time-point (t-1). The time-intervals used were 0-15, 15-30, 30-45, 45-60, 60-90, 90-120. Positive and higher scores indicate greater reduction in pain. SPIDt = ∑PID x (timet - timet-1) Pain Intensity was assessed at baseline and at each time-point based on a 4-point categorical Verbal Rating Scale (VRS) scale: 0-no pain, 1-mild pain, 2-moderate pain, 3-severe pain. If the subject rated pain intensity as "2" or "3", pain was assessed using a 100 mm Visual Analog Scale (VAS) [0 (no pain), 100 (worst pain)]. VAS scores were converted into PID scores by subtracting them from pain scores taken at baseline.
outcome.time_frame: Every two hours from baseline to 2 hours post dose
outcome.population: ITT population: All participants who received one study treatment and have at least one post-baseline efficacy assessment. Participants who did not achieve first perceptible pain relief during the 6 hours of the study period or took rescue medication were censored at the time 360 minutes.

outcome.title: Participants Global Assessment to Response to Treatment (PGART)
outcome.description: PGART was measured by a score in a scale from 0-4: 0- Poor; 1- Fair 2- Good; 3- Very Good; 4- Excellent.
outcome.population: ITT population: All participants who received study treatment and had at least one post-baseline efficacy assessment.

reported_events.time_frame: All adverse events encountered or spontaneously reported following administration of any investigational product, or for up to 5 days after the last administration of investigational product were recorded.

certain_agreements.pi_employee: Principal Investigators are NOT employed by the organization sponsoring the study.
certain_agreements.restrictive_agreement: GSK agreements may vary with individual investigators, but will not prohibit any investigator from publishing. GSK supports the publication of results from all centers of a multi-center trial but requests that reports based on single-site data not precede the primary publication of the entire clinical trial.
